subject: Fashion
title: Runway Shows Going Co-Ed
description: A 60-second lesson on Runway Shows Going Co-Ed.

hook.text: In 2016, Gucci merged its men's and women's shows into one. Other houses quickly followed.

buildup.text: Traditionally, menswear and womenswear showed in separate cities during separate weeks.

discovery.text: Alessandro Michele's Gucci blurred gender lines on the runway. Models wore whatever suited them.

twist.text: The practical reason? Showing one collection saves millions in production costs.

climax.text: Art or economicsâ€”either way, the message was clear: separating clothes by gender was outdated.

punchline.text: Fashion merged its runways. The binary split wasn't worth it.

quiz.question: What was one practical reason fashion houses merged men's and women's runway shows?
options: Models demanded equal pay regardless of gender
Social media audiences preferred watching combined shows
Showing one collection instead of two saves millions in costs
